natural problem: What is the probability that if you roll two fair, standard six-sided dice, the difference between the two numbers rolled will be 0? Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: If the difference between the two rolls is 0, then the rolls must be the same. Regardless of what the first roll is, the second roll is the same with $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$ probability.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "rat \<Rightarrow> rat"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>x. 1/6)"
and h1 : "finite {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h2 : "\<forall>x. x \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} \<longrightarrow> P x \<ge> 0"
and h3 : "sum P {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} = 1"
shows  "(\<Sum>x \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}. P x * P x) = 1 / 6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that if you roll two fair, standard six-sided dice, the difference between the two numbers rolled will be 0? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 If the difference between the two rolls is 0, then the rolls must be the same. Regardless of what the first roll is, the second roll is the same with $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$ probability.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "rat \<Rightarrow> rat"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>x. 1/6)"
and h1 : "finite {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h2 : "\<forall>x. x \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} \<longrightarrow> P x \<ge> 0"
and h3 : "sum P {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} = 1"
shows  "(\<Sum>x \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}. P x * P x) = 1 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a probability function $P(x) = \frac{1}{6}$ for the finite set $\{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$ with non-negative probabilities and a total probability of 1, calculate the sum of the squares of the probabilities, i.e., $\sum_{x \in \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}} P(x)^2$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{6}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "p > 0"
and h1 : "p = card { (a, b) | a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> a - b = 0 } / card { (a, b) | a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} }"
shows  "p = 1 / 6"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that if you roll two fair, standard six-sided dice, the difference between the two numbers rolled will be 0? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 If the difference between the two rolls is 0, then the rolls must be the same. Regardless of what the first roll is, the second roll is the same with $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$ probability.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "p > 0"
and h1 : "p = card { (a, b) | a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> a - b = 0 } / card { (a, b) | a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} }"
shows  "p = 1 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given the probability $p$ of rolling two six-sided dice (with sides numbered 1 to 6) and having the numbers on both dice be equal, find the value of $p$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{6}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (card {(a, b) |a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> a - b = 0}) / (card ({1..6} \<times> {1..6}))"
shows  "p = 1 / 6"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that if you roll two fair, standard six-sided dice, the difference between the two numbers rolled will be 0? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 If the difference between the two rolls is 0, then the rolls must be the same. Regardless of what the first roll is, the second roll is the same with $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$ probability.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (card {(a, b) |a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> a - b = 0}) / (card ({1..6} \<times> {1..6}))"
shows  "p = 1 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: What is the probability of getting the same number on both dice when rolling two fair six-sided dice? The final answer is $\frac{1}{6}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "p = 1 / 6"
shows  "p = (card {(a, b). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> a - b = 0}) / (card {1..6} * card {1..6})"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that if you roll two fair, standard six-sided dice, the difference between the two numbers rolled will be 0? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 If the difference between the two rolls is 0, then the rolls must be the same. Regardless of what the first roll is, the second roll is the same with $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$ probability.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "p = 1 / 6"
shows  "p = (card {(a, b). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> a - b = 0}) / (card {1..6} * card {1..6})"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: What is the probability of getting two equal numbers when rolling two fair 6-sided dice? Express your answer as a fraction. The final answer is $\frac{1}{6}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum>i \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}. \<Sum>j \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}. if i = j then 1 else 0) / 36"
shows  "p = 1 / 6"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that if you roll two fair, standard six-sided dice, the difference between the two numbers rolled will be 0? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 If the difference between the two rolls is 0, then the rolls must be the same. Regardless of what the first roll is, the second roll is the same with $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$ probability.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum>i \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}. \<Sum>j \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}. if i = j then 1 else 0) / 36"
shows  "p = 1 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the probability $p$ that when rolling two six-sided dice, both dice show the same number. The final answer is $\frac{1}{6}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum> i = 1..6. (\<Sum> j = 1..6. if i = j then 1 else 0)) / 36"
shows  "p = 1/6"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that if you roll two fair, standard six-sided dice, the difference between the two numbers rolled will be 0? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 If the difference between the two rolls is 0, then the rolls must be the same. Regardless of what the first roll is, the second roll is the same with $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$ probability.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum> i = 1..6. (\<Sum> j = 1..6. if i = j then 1 else 0)) / 36"
shows  "p = 1/6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the probability $p$ of rolling two fair six-sided dice and getting the same number on both dice. The final answer is $\frac{1}{6}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: "rat \<Rightarrow> rat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. (x \<ge> 0 \<and> x \<le> 6) \<longrightarrow> prob x = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "prob (\<lambda>x y. x - y) = (\<Sum>x = 1..6. \<Sum>y = 1..6. if x - y = 0 then 1 else 0) / 36"
shows  "prob (\<lambda>x y. x - y) = 1 / 6"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that if you roll two fair, standard six-sided dice, the difference between the two numbers rolled will be 0? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 If the difference between the two rolls is 0, then the rolls must be the same. Regardless of what the first roll is, the second roll is the same with $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$ probability.
 *)

theorem
fixes prob :: "rat \<Rightarrow> rat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. (x \<ge> 0 \<and> x \<le> 6) \<longrightarrow> prob x = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "prob (\<lambda>x y. x - y) = (\<Sum>x = 1..6. \<Sum>y = 1..6. if x - y = 0 then 1 else 0) / 36"
shows  "prob (\<lambda>x y. x - y) = 1 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In a fair 6-sided die, the probability of a specific number, say $x$, showing up is $\frac{1}{6}$ for $0 \le x \le 6$. What is the probability of the difference between two rolls, $x$ and $y$, being equal to 0? The final answer is $\frac{1}{6}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>x \<in>{1..6}. \<Sum>y \<in>{1..6}. if x - y = 0 then 1 else 0) / (\<Sum>x \<in>{1..6}. \<Sum>y \<in>{1..6}. 1)"
shows  "P = 1 / 6"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that if you roll two fair, standard six-sided dice, the difference between the two numbers rolled will be 0? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 If the difference between the two rolls is 0, then the rolls must be the same. Regardless of what the first roll is, the second roll is the same with $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$ probability.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>x \<in>{1..6}. \<Sum>y \<in>{1..6}. if x - y = 0 then 1 else 0) / (\<Sum>x \<in>{1..6}. \<Sum>y \<in>{1..6}. 1)"
shows  "P = 1 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: What is the probability of getting the same number on both dice when rolling two fair six-sided dice? The final answer is $\frac{1}{6}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..6}. \<Sum> j \<in> {1..6}. if i - j = 0 then 1 else 0) / (real (card ({1..6} \<times> {1..6})))"
shows  "p = 1 / 6"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that if you roll two fair, standard six-sided dice, the difference between the two numbers rolled will be 0? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 If the difference between the two rolls is 0, then the rolls must be the same. Regardless of what the first roll is, the second roll is the same with $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$ probability.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..6}. \<Sum> j \<in> {1..6}. if i - j = 0 then 1 else 0) / (real (card ({1..6} \<times> {1..6})))"
shows  "p = 1 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: What is the probability of getting the same number when rolling two fair six-sided dice? The final answer is $\frac{1}{6}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "p = 1 / 6"
shows  "p = (\<Sum> x \<in> {1..6}. (if x = x then 1 else 0)) / (6 * 6)"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that if you roll two fair, standard six-sided dice, the difference between the two numbers rolled will be 0? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{6}
 ### Proof
 If the difference between the two rolls is 0, then the rolls must be the same. Regardless of what the first roll is, the second roll is the same with $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$ probability.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "p = 1 / 6"
shows  "p = (\<Sum> x \<in> {1..6}. (if x = x then 1 else 0)) / (6 * 6)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given that the probability $p$ is equal to $\frac{1}{6}$, show that $p$ can also be expressed as the sum of a series: $\frac{\sum_{x=1}^6 (1 \text{ if } x = x, 0 \text{ otherwise})}{6 \times 6}$.
